EDITORIAL Dear Friends, July, 1979 It is with great pride and pleasure that we at Cash Box mark our 37th year of ser- vice to the music industry. While the recorded music business continues to change and grow in accordance with shifts in popular tastes, so have we paralleled those changes by improving and expanding our coverage of this ex- citing industry. And our magazine will continue to bring you the most thorough and timely reporting on our business available. The past year has seen the record and tape industry surpass the $4 billion mark for the first time with another 1 8% last year with unit sales rising 66%. And a whole new branch of the industry seems ready to explode with the introduction of the video disc in two markets and the growing use of in-store video. The phenomenal growth of the disco market has been another boon to the music industry in the past year, and Cash Box has reflected this with expanded editorial and chart coverage of this area. Extensive coverage has also monitored the formation of the Black Music Association, which has undertaken the important task of guiding the economic growth of black music. Along with keeping you abreast of these changes, Cash Box has aggressively strengthened our general news coverage as the face of the industry changes through mergers, distribution shifts and the formation of new companies. In addi- tion, we have honed our chart research methodology so it more accurately reflects up-to-the-minute trends in pop, black contemporary, country, disco, jazz, classical, Latin, gospel and numerous international record markets. On the retail front, Cash Box has beefed up the merchandising section of the magazine, which now includes a weekly column devoted exclusively to the retail community in addition to our breakout listings and our regular stories on impor- tant developments in this area. Radio is another focal point, with editorial attention given to this key area complementing our extensive Regional Programming Guide and other weekly radio features. Our coverage of the jukebox business, which represents the bread and butter of the 45 rpm record, is a trendsetter in the industry. And our reporting on the en- tire coin machine industry is unmatched by any other music publication. As we begin our 38th year, we at Cash Box will continue to bring you the full story behind the events that shape the future of the music industry and we pledge to fully explore new aspects of the business as they emerge. Finally, we wish to ex- press our gratitude for the trust you have placed in us. We look forward to your continued support and inputinthecoming year. Together, wecan build astronger industry. Arpeggio 25. 10CC Just one year ago we an- nounced to the world that from our strong foundation we were going to build a new Polydor. And we introduced artists and albums to spark that growth. Now we’d like to bring you up to date on just what’s been happening at the Big Red Label. AN EXCITING YEAR WAS HAD BY ALL We doubled our sales. Our artists earned so many Gold and Platinum records we’re running out of wall space. We set company records for the most # 1 chart po- sitions. We set singles action rec- ords. We brought established artists to new career levels like At- lanta Rhythm Section to Plati- num, Peaches &. Herb to Multi- Platinum, Millie Jackson to Gold, Robert Fripp, Pat Travers, Roy Ayers, Chick Corea, and James Brown to wider audiences. And we successfully launched new art- ists like Alicia Bridges, and Frank Mills with Gold Records first time out. Our artists dominated the disco explosion, with Gloria Gay- nor, Alicia Bridges, Peaches &. Herb, Alton McClain &. Destiny, and Don Ray crossing over. Bionic Boogie, Arpeggio, and French Kiss kept the dancing going. And Michele Freeman, Don Ray’s first project under a production agree- ment concentrates his multi-tal- ents as writer-arranger-musician- producer. Nothing fuels enthusiasm and excitement for us, and for our artists, like success. In the past year, success has become con- tagious. New albums from Blackjack , Philip D’Arrow, Bram Tchaikovsky and Missouri are already catching fire. And soon to be released albums from Rainbow, Buckeye and Darling promise to do the same. BGO The producer/manager team of Buddy Buie and Arnie Geller are off to a flying start with Atlanta Rhythm Sec- tion’s "Underdog.” And soon to come is a new album from the star of "I Love The Nightlife,” Alicia Bridges. Charisma Records The famous Charis- ma label hangs its hat with Polydor in the U.S. The reception given artists like Patrick Moraz, Peter Hammill, Hawk- lords and the forthcoming album from Darling makes one feel at home.
